Dear Romell Green:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12326
Section • (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
Description another agency the borrowing agency shall have a record
containing all the following:
• (a) Approval from the certifying agency authorizing
the placement of a child in the home.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency placed a youth in foster home certified by another agency
without notifying the agency. Placement of the youth put the home
over the approved capacity and there is no borrowed bed
agreement in place.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on February 28,
2025. They reported no additional information.
Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on February
28, 2025. FP stated the situation was very confusing. Guiding
Harbor had informed her she was originally licensed for 2 youth
however, an addendum was in process to increase her licensing
capacity to 4. She was under the impression the addendum had
been completed but the agency later told her it hadn’t been
completed. At one point she had Youth A and her baby and the
agency placed another youth. The other youth went AWOL shortly
after being placed in her home and Guiding Harbor contacted her
about taking another youth and her baby. FP told them no
because she was probably going to be taking Youth B who is
Youth A’s sister.
FP stated Youth B was placed through Whaley and MDHHS. She
clarified she communicated with Whaley regarding placement of
Youth B prior to her being placed in her home. FP stated there
had been ongoing conversations regarding potential placement of
Youth B for some time. She stated MDHHS FC supervisor had
advised they needed to slow down to ensure the placement was
done properly and everything was in order because Whaley was
trying to push it through quickly.
PAFC Foster Care Program Manager (PAFC FC PM) was
interviewed via telephone on February 28, 2025. She stated the
agency became aware on February 24, 2025, that Youth B had
been placed with FP. She stated Youth B has been in the
placement since January 24, 2025. She stated FP and MDHHS
reported Whaley had reached out to FP regarding placement of
Youth B. Youth B was in Whaley at the time and had done sibling
visits with Youth A in FP’s home. She stated a referral had been
made to RPU to assist in locating a placement for Youth B. During
a recent meeting with MDHHS someone reported prior to Youth B
being placed they were trying to get Whaley to slow down
because things were moving too fast and needed to ensure things
were in place if Youth B was to be placed in FP’s home. She could
not recall who made those comments. PAFC FC PM stated the
2

agency was never notified by anyone that placement was being
considered in FP’s home.
MDHHS Foster Care supervisor (MDHHS FC supervisor) was
interviewed via video conference on March 4, 2025. She stated
her agency had been looking for a placement for Youth B for a
long time. RPU as well as Wayne Co. placement unit has been
looped in the placement search. RPU sent an email saying they
had been informed about a placement with FP who also has
placement of her sister, Youth A so they are going to close out
their referral. MDHHS FC supervisor immediately responded and
informed RPU they hadn’t initiated any placement with FP and
there had not been any communication between FP and MDHHS
directly indicating this was a placement they were looking into.
She asked if they could give her time to look into everything and
then go from there. RPU responded and indicated Whaley
reported Youth B had been visiting in the home on the weekends,
so they went ahead and closed out their referral. MDHHS FC
supervisor again asked them not to close the referral and they
have not had any communication regarding DOC or anything and
all of the communication up until that point was with Whaley. RPU
was adamant they would close out the referral and they didn’t
have additional communication beyond that. She contacted FP
and asked where she received information regarding possible
placement. FP reported she had been in communication with
Whaley and they had negotiated a specific DOC rate for Youth B.
MDHHS FC supervisor asked MDHHS FCW to schedule a
placement change TDM and invite everyone so there could be
discussion on what needed to be done on their end for Youth B to
be placed with FP. She stated she was trying to include anyone
she could think of to assist but she didn’t include their licensing
staff because at that point she was trying to have everyone
involved to stop and allow her time to review the case and see
what was going on and what needed to be done. MDHHS FC
supervisor stated after the TDM the placement change moved
forward and MDHHS staff transported Youth B to the FP’s home.
FP reported during the TDM she thought she had room for 2 youth
and had declined placement for another youth so she could
accept Youth B. FP reported she spoke to Guiding Harbor about
taking placement of Youth B. FC supervisor thought she had
invited all of the appropriate people to the TDM in order to move
forward.
MDHHS FC supervisor clarified RPU had been involved since
September or October 2024. They contacted MDHHS FC
3

supervisor directly in January and said placement had been found
for Youth B so they were going to close their referral. She thought
it was strange they didn’t give her a chance to sort things out
before abruptly closing the referral. MDHHS thought since FP is
licensed and everyone was aware of the plan and Youth B had a
discharge date they moved her. FP had reported she was in
contact with Guiding Harbor about Youth B because both
agencies were making attempts to obtain a bed for her.
MDHHS Foster Care worker (MDHHS FCW) was interviewed
via telephone on March 7, 2025. She stated there was
communication between RPU and Wayne Co Placement Unit
regarding placement of Youth B. There were some visits at FP’s
home between Youth A and Youth B so FP was familiar with
Youth B. FP had stated she was willing to take placement of
Youth B and indicated she had communicated that with Guiding
Harbor.
MDHHS FCW stated RPU abruptly closed out their referral and
MDHHS FC supervisor had asked them to slow the process down
to make sure everything was appropriate. At that point, Youth B
was placed with FP. MDHHS FCW stated she picked up Youth B
from Whaley and transported her to FP’s house. MDHHS FCW
stated she did not have communication with anyone from Guiding
Harbor regarding Youth B being placed with FP. She stated when
Youth A was placed with FP, Guiding Harbor provided her will all
of the documents necessary to place her and asked MDHHS FCW
to obtain FP’s signatures on some documents and send back to
them.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth B’s MISACWIS case record.
-January 9, 2025, social work contact written by MDHHS
FCW. A face-to-face visit was conducted with Youth B.
Youth B stated that she is doing well and has no safety
concerns to report. Youth B stated that her visits over the
break went well. Youth B stated that she is looking forward
to being placed in the home with her sister.
-January 23, 2025, written by MDHHS FCW. Placement
change TDM for Youth B as a foster home has been
secured and she has completed residential. The
recommendation for Youth B is to be released from the
residential and placed in a licensed foster home.
-January 24, 2025, written by MDHHS FCW. A face-to-face
visit was conducted with Youth B. Youth B was discharged
4

from Whaley Children's Center. Youth B was taken to her
foster home placement with FP.
Analysis The agency is found to be in noncompliance. Although there was
confusion due to Whaley communicating directly with FP and not
including MDHHS, MDHHS FCW (the agency with foster care
case management responsibility) was involved in conversations
and transported Youth B to the foster home as noted in her social
work contacts. However, no communication occurred with
MDHHS licensing department or Guiding Harbor licensing
department to ensure appropriate borrowed bed forms completed
prior to placement.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
